signals.title: Jan 2026 BLS Final: 130K Jobs, 2025 Revised to 181K Total — Labor Market Weaker Than Believed
signals.source: BLS Employment Situation (Feb 11, 2026), Indeed Hiring Lab (Feb 11, 2026)
key_data: 130K nonfarm payrolls added in January 2026 (vs 55K consensus — upside surprise)
2025 annual benchmark revision: total jobs revised from 584K to 181K — only 15K/month average
Four months of 2025 now show net job losses (Jan, Jun, Aug, Oct) — previously only three
862K downward revision (not seasonally adjusted) — second-largest on record after 2009
Healthcare added 81.9K (63% of total), social assistance 42K, construction 33K
signals.implication: The 2025 labor market was dramatically weaker than reported in real-time. 15K/month average is recessionary-level job creation masked by measurement lag. The Jan 2026 beat (130K vs 55K) provides some optimism, but the healthcare share (63%) confirms continued healthcare monoculture. The revision from 584K to 181K means policy decisions throughout 2025 were based on materially incorrect data. This is the final confirmation of the 898K preliminary revision flagged in v3-7.

signals.title: Federal Workforce Down 212K (9%) — DOGE Cuts Now Structural
key_data: Federal civilian workforce reduced by ~212,000 — roughly 9% of 2.3M total
300K layoffs announced in first year; Defense Dept lost 60K+, Treasury 30K+, Agriculture 20K+
BLS Jan 2026 report shows -34K federal government jobs as DOGE deferred resignations hit payrolls
Black women disproportionately affected: 319K job losses between Feb-Jul 2025
Some agencies now recalling fired workers — admits overcutting in critical functions
signals.implication: DOGE cuts have moved from policy disruption to structural labor market force. 9% workforce reduction in one year is unprecedented in modern federal employment. The recall of fired workers signals overcutting that damaged operational capacity. -34K federal jobs showing up in Jan 2026 BLS report means the cuts are now visible in headline employment data. This is both a demographic event (concentrated impact on specific groups) and a geographic one (D.C., Virginia, Maryland metros restructuring).

signals.title: Operation PARRIS — Refugee Reverification Escalates Immigration Enforcement to New Legal Territory
key_data: 5,600 Minnesota refugees targeted for retroactive reverification under Operation PARRIS
Armed ICE agents conducting door-to-door arrests of legally admitted refugees
Federal judge issued temporary restraining order on Jan 28 — preliminary injunction hearing Feb 19
Minnesota AG launched class-action lawsuit against DHS
Follows Operation Metro Surge: 2,000 agents, ~3,000 arrests in Minneapolis-St Paul
signals.implication: Operation PARRIS extends immigration enforcement from unauthorized immigrants to legally admitted refugees — a qualitative escalation. If the government can retroactively revoke refugee status, it creates uncertainty for all immigration pathways including employment visas. This is the legal frontier where immigration enforcement meets labor supply: workers with legal status can no longer assume stability, chilling workforce participation in immigrant-heavy sectors (healthcare, meatpacking, construction). The federal court injunction creates a constitutional test case.

signals.title: Nursing Shortage Executing: 8% National Deficit, 250K RN Gap by 2030
key_data: National nursing supply meets 91.94% of demand in 2026 — 8.06% shortage rate
Licensed practical nurses: 20% shortage; registered nurses: 10% shortage
100K nurses left workforce in past two years; 92K qualified nursing school applicants rejected in 2021
250K+ RN shortage projected by 2030
CA, TX, FL most severe shortages due to population growth + aging demographics
signals.implication: The nursing shortage is now measurable and worsening. 8% national deficit means healthcare is simultaneously the only sector creating jobs AND unable to fill those jobs. The 92K rejected nursing school applicants reveals a supply-side bottleneck (faculty shortage, limited seats) that cannot be solved quickly. This creates a paradox: healthcare accounts for 63% of job creation but faces structural inability to meet its own labor demand. Immigration restrictions compound the problem as 15%+ of nurses are foreign-born.

signals.title: California College of the Arts Closure — 119-Year Institution Falls to Demographic Cliff
key_data: California College of the Arts (est. 1907) closing after 2026-2027 academic year
Vanderbilt University purchasing the campus — asset consolidation by well-endowed institutions
Siena Heights University (MI) also closing; Martin University (HBCU, IN) ceased operations
16 colleges closed in 2025, following 28 in 2024 and 14 in 2023 — accelerating trend
Bloomberg: demographic enrollment cliff begins with class of 2026
signals.implication: A 119-year-old California institution closing is a marker event — this is not just small rural colleges. Vanderbilt purchasing the campus demonstrates the emerging pattern: well-endowed institutions cannibalize weaker ones for assets. The HBCU closure (Martin University) adds an equity dimension. Accelerating closure rate (14 -> 28 -> 16 -> tracking higher) confirms the demographic cliff is executing as projected. Higher education is entering structural contraction that reshapes local economies and professional pipelines.

signals.title: India Tech Job Market: 12-15% Growth BUT 60% Below Peak Openings
signals.source: Avenue Mail (2026), BW Businessworld (2026), New India Abroad (2026)
key_data: India tech job market projected to grow 12-15% in 2026, creating ~125K new roles
Active tech openings at 103K in Jan 2026 — 60% below early 2022 peak
52% of US tech/banking professionals say their firms plan to increase India hiring in 2026
93% of global firms (Google, Amazon, Microsoft, etc.) reporting India hiring expansion plans
AI/ML, cybersecurity, semiconductor roles surged 51% as experimental -> core business
signals.implication: India's tech labor market shows a split personality: growth in AI/ML roles (51% surge) coexists with overall openings 60% below peak. The critical signal is the 93% of global firms expanding India hiring — this confirms the H-1B wage-weighted lottery is accelerating offshoring rather than just filtering immigration. Combined with India's zero-tax AI policy, the talent flow is inverting: instead of Indian workers coming to US, US companies are deploying work to India. This reshapes the global tech labor supply chain.

signals.title: Immigration Enforcement Hitting Construction and Agriculture — Worksite Raids Causing Cascading Delays
key_data: Arrests of people with no criminal record surged 2,450% in Trump's first year
Construction groups in southern Texas report aggressive worksite raids causing project delays
Materials supplier laid off workers; one concrete company filed bankruptcy from raid-related sales drop
Nearly 69K people in ICE detention as of early Jan 2026
Two US citizens fatally shot by federal agents in Minneapolis in January 2026
signals.implication: Immigration enforcement is now a measurable economic force in construction and agriculture. The 2,450% surge in no-criminal-record arrests means enforcement has shifted from targeting criminals to broad workforce sweeps. Worksite raids creating construction delays and a concrete company bankruptcy demonstrate the economic transmission mechanism: enforcement -> worker fear -> labor withdrawal -> project delays -> business failures. This compounds the pre-existing construction labor crisis (723K monthly openings, 6-8% wage inflation).

signals.title: Hyperscaler AI Capex Approaching $700B — Free Cash Flow Collapse Across Big Tech
key_data: Combined 2026 capex guidance: Amazon $200B, Alphabet $175-185B, Meta $115-135B, Microsoft ~$80B
Total hyperscaler AI capex approaching $700B — up 60%+ from 2025's historic levels
Amazon projected negative FCF of -$17B to -$28B in 2026 (Morgan Stanley / BofA estimates)
Alphabet FCF projected to drop ~90% to $8.2B from $73.3B (Pivotal Research)
Meta FCF expected to compress ~50% to ~$25B
signals.implication: This is the largest coordinated corporate capital deployment in history. $700B in a single year from 4-5 companies approaches the GDP of entire nations. Amazon going FCF-negative and Alphabet losing 90% of FCF means these companies are betting their financial flexibility on AI infrastructure payoff. If AI revenue scales to match, this creates an unassailable moat. If it doesn't, this is the largest capital misallocation since the telecom bubble. The stock reactions (Amazon -4%, Alphabet -3%, Meta +10%) show markets are split on whether this is visionary or reckless.

signals.title: AI Capex Reckoning Week — Markets Flash Correction Signals as Earnings Collide with Infrastructure Reality
key_data: S&P 500 tested 6,144 then rallied toward 7,000 — extreme volatility in first week of Feb
AI heavyweights face 'capex reckoning' — market breadth surging as rotation begins
Momentum gauges flashing warning as massive capital outflows from tech giants
Top 7 companies = 53% of S&P 500 returns, greatest concentration in half a century
Morgan Stanley: current leaders have 3x cash reserves vs dot-com era — not identical bubble dynamics
signals.implication: The first week of Feb 2026 may mark a regime change in AI market psychology. For the first time, massive capex announcements are being punished rather than rewarded. Market breadth surging while tech leaders face outflows suggests rotation from AI infrastructure beneficiaries to the broader market. 53% concentration in top 7 stocks is a systemic fragility — a 20% correction in those names would be a ~10% index decline. The dot-com comparison is imperfect (3x cash reserves) but concentration levels are comparable.

signals.title: CMBS Overall Delinquency Hits 7.47% — Office Remains Epicenter but Contagion Spreading
key_data: Overall CMBS delinquency rose to 7.47% in January 2026 — up 17bp from December
Office CMBS delinquency at all-time high entering 2026 (11.76% at year-end 2025, still climbing)
$936B in CRE mortgages maturing in 2026 — one-fifth are office-related
1,788 banks have CRE exposure >300% of equity capital (up from 1,697 prior quarter)
Provisions for loan losses could rise to 24% of net revenue in 2026 (vs 20.8% in 2025)
signals.implication: CRE stress is now spreading beyond office. The 17bp monthly increase in overall CMBS delinquency shows the contagion v3-7 flagged is materializing. 1,788 banks with CRE >300% of equity is up 91 banks from prior quarter — the risk pool is growing, not shrinking. $936B in 2026 maturities is a wall that refinancing cannot fully absorb, especially with the Fed holding rates. The 24% provision forecast means bank earnings will be pressured even if no systemic event occurs.

signals.title: Humanoid Robotics Funding Explodes 300% — Physical AI Capital Formation Accelerates
key_data: Apptronik raised $520M at $5B valuation (Feb 11) — total Series A now $935M
Skild AI raised $1.4B at $14B valuation (Jan 14) — SoftBank, Nvidia, Bezos backed
Figure AI at $39B valuation after $1B Series C (Sep 2025) — nearly $2B total raised
VC funding for humanoid robotics up 300% year-over-year
Google DeepMind, Mercedes-Benz, John Deere among strategic investors — industrial deployment signal
signals.implication: Physical AI is undergoing the same capital formation phase that software AI saw in 2023-2024, but at an even faster pace. 300% YoY funding growth and three companies at $5B-$39B valuations signal VC conviction that humanoid robotics is the next major platform. The strategic investor mix (Google, Mercedes, John Deere, Qatar sovereign fund) means this is not just VC speculation — industrial users are pre-positioning. This directly addresses the demographic labor shortage: humanoid robots are being built for logistics, manufacturing, and data center operations where workers are unavailable.

signals.title: PE Entering 2026 Split: Mega-Deals Stall, Mid-Market Sees Pent-Up Demand
key_data: 80%+ of PE respondents expect deal volumes and values to rise — but confidence favors modest growth
Traditional LBOs constrained by leverage limitations and persistent valuation gaps
Average PE middle market term loan funding cost down 3pp from peak — easing but not normalized
$620B+ in high-yield bonds and leveraged loans approaching maturity in 2026-2027
Leading firms expanding into real assets, infrastructure, hybrid capital — diversifying from pure LBO
signals.implication: PE's bifurcation into mega-deals (stalled) and mid-market (recovering) creates a two-speed M&A environment. The 3pp cost reduction helps but doesn't restore 2021-era economics. $620B in approaching maturities forces resolution — either refinance at higher rates or sell. The strategic pivot to infrastructure, real assets, and hybrid capital means PE is de facto becoming an infrastructure investor, which aligns with the $700B hyperscaler capex build. PE capital is following the AI infrastructure buildout.

signals.title: Tariff Economic Impact Crystallizing: $1,300/Household, -0.7% GDP, Jobless Expansion
key_data: Trump tariffs = average $1,300 tax increase per household in 2026 (up from $1,000 in 2025)
Long-run GDP reduced by 0.7% from tariffs plus retaliatory tariffs combined
Federal tariff revenue +$171.1B (0.54% of GDP) — largest tax hike since 1993
$200B in collective tariff bills across US states from March 2025 through Nov 2025
Three House Republicans bucked leadership to block tariff authority transfer to White House
signals.implication: Tariffs are now a measurable macro drag, not just a threat. $1,300/household is a direct consumption tax that compounds the consumer frugality signal from v3-7. The 'jobless expansion' framing is critical: tariffs create GDP growth (through import substitution) but not job growth (because reshored production is automated). This is a structural shift where trade policy amplifies the AI automation dynamic rather than offsetting it. Political cracks (3 GOP defections) suggest tariff regime may face legislative challenge in midterms.

signals.title: Fed January Hold Confirmed — 'Dual Mandate in Balance' Signals Extended Pause
key_data: FOMC held rate at 3.50-3.75% unanimously in January
Removed language about higher risk from weakening labor market — now sees dual goals 'more in balance'
Philly Fed president Paulson: 'decent chance' inflation close to 2% on run-rate basis by year-end
Bowman: 'increasingly confident' tariff effects on goods inflation will wane
Market pricing: only one cut likely in 2026 amid policy disagreements
signals.implication: The Fed removing the labor market risk language is significant — it signals they see the revised-down employment data as stabilization rather than deterioration. 'More in balance' means the bar for rate cuts has risen; the Fed needs convincing evidence of either labor weakness or inflation at target. With only one cut priced for 2026, the rate environment remains restrictive for CRE refinancing, PE portfolio companies, and consumer credit. The tariff-inflation interaction remains the wildcard.

signals.title: Gartner: AI in Trough of Disillusionment — Fewer Than 30% of CEOs Satisfied with ROI
key_data: Gartner places AI in Trough of Disillusionment throughout 2026
Average enterprise AI investment: $1.9M per project; fewer than 30% of AI leaders report CEO satisfaction
Forrester: enterprises will defer 25% of planned AI spend into 2027 due to ROI concerns
Only 15% of AI decision-makers report AI-related earnings increases in past year
$2.52T global AI spending in 2026 — but scaling follows only when ROI becomes predictable
signals.implication: The enterprise AI psychology has bifurcated: hyperscalers are spending $700B because they must (infrastructure lock-in), while enterprise buyers are pulling back because they can (ROI not proven). 25% spend deferral is the enterprise version of 'show me the money.' This creates a dangerous gap: the infrastructure is being built at unprecedented scale, but the paying enterprise customers are hesitating. If the deferral pattern persists, AI infrastructure becomes overcapacity — the classic boom-bust pattern. This is the psychology that could break the capex cycle.

signals.title: Job Hugging: 64% of Workers Staying in Roles Out of AI Fear Despite Burnout
key_data: 64% of surveyed workers 'job hugging' — remaining in current roles despite dissatisfaction
Complete reversal from Great Resignation era — fear replaces mobility
Burnout and skill shortages persist but workers won't risk job changes
35% confidence decrease among baby boomers; 25% drop among Gen X
13% increase in AI tool usage concurrent with 18% confidence collapse
signals.implication: Job hugging is a new psychological phenomenon with structural economic consequences. When 64% of workers refuse to change jobs due to AI fear, labor market fluidity collapses. This means: (1) workers stay in suboptimal roles, reducing productivity; (2) employers lose the efficiency gains from natural turnover; (3) wage growth stagnates because switching premium disappears; (4) innovation slows because entrepreneurial risk-taking declines. This is fear-driven labor market sclerosis — the opposite of what AI adoption requires.

signals.title: Google/Ipsos: Global AI Sentiment Split 50/50 — Create Jobs vs Destroy Jobs
key_data: Respondents evenly split: 50% believe AI will create new jobs, 50% believe it will eliminate jobs
Survey conducted across multiple countries — this is a global finding
No demographic consensus on AI employment impact — maximum uncertainty
Workers who use AI daily are more optimistic; non-users more fearful
signals.implication: A perfect 50/50 split on AI job impact is itself a signal of maximum uncertainty. When society cannot form consensus on whether a technology is beneficial or harmful, adoption decisions become paralyzed. The experience gap (users optimistic, non-users fearful) confirms the v3-7 Edelman finding that trust is experience-driven. But the 50/50 global split means the AI trust problem is not solvable by education alone — half the population has heard the arguments and still concludes AI destroys jobs. Policy and institutional frameworks must address this structural ambiguity.

signals.title: HBR Confirms: Companies Laying Off for AI 'Potential' Not Performance
key_data: HBR: companies cutting headcount based on AI's potential capability, not demonstrated replacement
Oxford Economics: macroeconomic data does not support structural AI-driven employment shift
55K jobs directly attributed to AI in 2025 (Challenger, Gray & Christmas) out of 1.17M total layoffs
Only 1% of services firms reported laying off workers because of AI (NY Fed survey)
Many layoffs are pandemic overhiring correction dressed up as AI-driven restructuring
signals.implication: HBR's framing crystallizes the AI-washing phenomenon: companies are making anticipatory cuts based on what AI might do, not what it has done. This creates a self-fulfilling prophecy: (1) companies announce AI-driven layoffs; (2) workers become more fearful; (3) fear drives job hugging and reduced consumption; (4) reduced consumption weakens the economy; (5) weakened economy justifies more layoffs. The 55K/1.17M ratio (4.7%) is the actual AI displacement rate vs the 60% narrative rate — a 12x gap between perception and reality.

signals.title: ChatGPT at 900M Weekly Users, 2.8B Monthly — Consumer AI Adoption Decoupled from Trust
key_data: ChatGPT: 900M weekly active users (Dec 2025), up from 500M in March 2025
2.8B monthly active users; 2.5B prompts sent daily
10M+ paying subscribers; OpenAI expects $29.4B revenue by 2026
81.13% market share in generative AI — dominant platform
49% of usage is 'Asking' (advice), 40% 'Doing' (tasks), 11% 'Expressing' (reflection)
signals.implication: Consumer AI adoption has reached mass-market scale (2.8B monthly) while trust surveys show 50/50 split and worker confidence collapsing. This is the usage-trust paradox: people use AI extensively while simultaneously distrusting it. The 49% 'asking' category — using AI as advisor — shows consumers are outsourcing judgment to a technology they claim to distrust. 81% market share means ChatGPT is becoming the default interface between humans and AI, with implications for information access, decision-making, and cognitive patterns at civilizational scale.

signals.title: Deepfake Escalation: 148% Surge in Impersonation Scams, Detection Systems Failing
key_data: 148% surge in AI-generated impersonation scams in 2025
30%+ of high-impact corporate impersonation attacks now involve deepfakes
Major retailers receiving 1,000+ AI-generated scam calls per day
AI-generated media now bypasses legacy detection tools with 90%+ success rate
NBC: experts warn of 'collapse of trust online' driven by AI-generated content
signals.implication: Deepfake threats have moved from theoretical to operational at scale. 148% surge and 90%+ detection evasion means the offense is outpacing defense decisively. When retailers get 1,000+ deepfake scam calls daily, the economics of trust verification become untenable with human processes. This accelerates demand for cryptographic provenance and hardware-level identity verification — an entire new infrastructure layer. The 'collapse of trust online' is not hyperbole; it's an ongoing structural shift that reprices every digitally-mediated transaction.

signals.title: 2026 State AI Legislative Explosion — Illinois, Oregon, Washington Leading Wave
key_data: 1,200+ AI bills introduced across all 50 states in 2025; 2026 on pace to exceed
Illinois: SB 3261 (chatbot safety), SB 3263 (AI provenance), multiple additional bills
Oregon and Washington advancing chatbot regulation bills
South Carolina: AI-powered vehicle tracking restrictions on law enforcement
Trump EO seeks federal preemption — but states continue passing laws in defiance
signals.implication: The state AI regulatory wave is accelerating despite federal preemption efforts. 1,200+ bills means every state legislature is grappling with AI governance simultaneously, creating a compliance patchwork that is increasingly impossible for multi-state companies to navigate. The Illinois cluster (multiple bills on different AI dimensions) signals a model state approach that others will copy. The federal-state conflict creates a litigation pipeline that will take years to resolve, meaning regulatory uncertainty is structural, not temporary.

signals.title: Tariff Bills Mounting in States — Affordability Meets AI Anxiety for Midterm Showdown
key_data: State-level tariff relief bills mounting as affordability becomes midterm election issue
$200B in collective tariff bills paid across US states March 2025 - Nov 2025
Top midterm-election states paid over $134B in tariffs
Inflation, affordability, and tariffs converging as political issue for 2026 midterms
Consumer sentiment remains fragile — dual pressure from tariff costs and AI job anxiety
signals.implication: Tariff affordability is becoming the political transmission mechanism for economic anxiety. When states start passing their own tariff relief bills, it signals the federal trade policy is creating measurable constituent pain. The convergence of tariff costs ($1,300/household) and AI job anxiety (64% job hugging) creates a compound anxiety that will dominate midterm politics. Policy uncertainty intensifies as both tariff and AI regulation become election issues — businesses face potential policy reversals in both dimensions.

signals.title: Financial Services Job Losses in Jan 2026 — -22K as AI Restructuring Begins
key_data: Financial activities lost 22,000 jobs in January 2026 per BLS
Federal government lost 34,000 jobs in same month
Financial sector losses come amid record bank earnings — cutting while profitable
AI-driven back-office automation in banking, insurance, and asset management accelerating
Financial sector is one of only two major sectors showing net job losses in January
signals.implication: Financial services losing 22K jobs while reporting record earnings is the clearest signal of AI-driven white-collar restructuring in BLS data to date. Unlike federal cuts (policy-driven) or construction (cyclical), financial sector cuts during peak profitability indicate structural workforce reduction. This is the sector where AI capability most directly replaces human cognitive tasks (underwriting, compliance, analysis, customer service). Combined with the HBR finding about anticipatory layoffs, financial services may be the leading indicator for broader white-collar AI displacement.

signals.title: AI Midterm Election Crossroads — Distrust Rising as AI Becomes Campaign Issue
key_data: AI trust becoming a campaign issue ahead of 2026 US midterm elections
52% of workers worry about AI's impact on their future (Pew Research)
Candidates increasingly positioning on AI regulation as voter-facing issue
Deepfake concerns merge with election integrity anxiety — dual trust threat
State-level AI legislation accelerating partly as campaign positioning
signals.implication: AI becoming an election issue changes the policy trajectory. When politicians compete on AI regulation platforms, the regulatory environment becomes unpredictable and subject to electoral cycles. Deepfake + election integrity creates a feedback loop where AI distrust amplifies democratic anxiety. The midterm outcome will determine whether federal preemption or state-level regulation wins — a binary policy event for the AI industry. Enterprise AI strategy must now account for political risk alongside technical and economic risk.

F2_demographics.rationale: 2025 revised to 181K total jobs (15K/month) — recessionary-level disguised by measurement lag. Federal workforce cut 9% by DOGE. Immigration enforcement escalated to legally admitted refugees (PARRIS). Nursing shortage quantified at 8% national deficit. College closures accelerating, now hitting 119-year institutions. India hiring expansion by 93% of global firms confirms H-1B system is accelerating offshoring. Construction labor crisis compounded by worksite raids.

F4_capital.change: upgraded: capex scale unprecedented, bifurcation widening
F4_capital.rationale: Hyperscaler capex approaching $700B with FCF turning negative (Amazon -$17-28B, Alphabet -90%). This is the largest corporate capital deployment in history. CMBS delinquency rising to 7.47% with 1,788 banks at >300% CRE/equity. Humanoid robotics funding up 300%. PE bifurcated between stalled mega-deals and recovering mid-market. Tariffs crystallizing at -0.7% GDP. Fed extended pause with only one cut priced. Financial services losing 22K jobs while reporting record earnings.

F5_psychology.change: confirmed and deepening with new phenomena emerging
F5_psychology.rationale: Job hugging (64% staying out of fear) is a new structural phenomenon. AI in Gartner Trough of Disillusionment; 25% of enterprise spend being deferred. Google/Ipsos shows perfect 50/50 global split on AI impact — maximum uncertainty. HBR confirms anticipatory layoffs (potential not performance). ChatGPT at 2.8B users while trust collapses — usage-trust paradox. Deepfake scams up 148% with 90%+ detection evasion. 1,200+ state AI bills. AI becoming midterm election issue.

new_pattern_candidates.name: Healthcare Employment Monoculture
new_pattern_candidates.description: Healthcare accounted for 63% of Jan 2026 jobs (81.9K/130K) and simultaneously faces 8% national nursing shortage. The only sector creating jobs cannot fill its own vacancies. 2025 revised to 181K total jobs reinforces single-sector dependency.

new_pattern_candidates.name: Toxic AI Adoption / Usage-Trust Paradox
new_pattern_candidates.description: Job hugging (64%) + ChatGPT 2.8B users + 25% enterprise spend deferral + 50/50 global sentiment split. People use AI extensively while simultaneously fearing and distrusting it. Adoption has decoupled from confidence. This paradox reduces productivity gains and creates fragile adoption patterns.

new_pattern_candidates.name: Anticipatory Displacement Loop
new_pattern_candidates.description: Companies lay off for AI potential (not performance). Workers fear replacement and job-hug. Fear reduces consumption. Reduced consumption weakens economy. Weakened economy justifies more layoffs. The loop is self-reinforcing and decoupled from actual AI capability. 55K actual AI layoffs vs 1.17M total, but perception drives behavior.

cross_force_interactions.interaction: Hyperscaler $700B capex is building infrastructure that addresses F2 labor shortage — but humanoid robotics (300% funding growth) is the capital-to-demographics bridge. Physical AI deployment directly substitutes for missing demographic cohorts in logistics, manufacturing, healthcare.

Immigration enforcement (PARRIS, worksite raids) creates labor supply fear that compounds AI job fear. Workers face dual threat: deportation risk if immigrant, AI replacement risk if native. This double anxiety drives the job hugging phenomenon and construction/agriculture labor withdrawal.

The capex-disillusionment gap: hyperscalers spending $700B while enterprises defer 25% of AI spend. Infrastructure is being built for demand that may not materialize at projected scale. If enterprise ROI doesn't improve, the $700B bet becomes stranded capital — and the psychology shifts from disillusionment to panic.
